elements.content: The mimic of a (3,9)-connected xmz framework generates a novel highly connected Co-metal–organic framework (SNNU-80) constructed by trigonal prismatic [Co3(OH)­(COO)6] building blocks and tripodal pyridyl-dicarboxylate ligands (BPYDB = 4,4′-(4,4′-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)-dibenzoic acid). Compared to the nonporous Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate xmz metal–organic framework (MOF), the extension of a triangular linker leads to a different geometrical distribution of ligands and thus a porous structure with the topology of 3,3,9T2 for SNNU-80. Four types of polyhedral cages coexist together, which produce permanent micro- and mesoporosity. Different from MCF-18 assembled by BPYDB with [Ni3(OH)­(COO)6] showing drastic framework breathing, SNNU-80 is not flexible. As a result, SNNU-80 shows remarkable CO2 uptake capacity as well as high CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons over CH4 selectivity. Furthermore, the electrochemical measurements show that SNNU-80 is an idea electrode material for supercapacitors due to its highly connected stable porous framework and the pseudocapacitor contribution introduced by the mixed valent system.
elements.clean_text: The mimic of a (3,9)-connected xmz framework generates a novel highly connected Co-metal-organic framework (SNNU-80) constructed by trigonal prismatic [Co3(OH)(COO)6] building blocks and tripodal pyridyl-dicarboxylate ligands (BPYDB = 4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)-dibenzoic acid). Compared to the nonporous Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate xmz metal-organic framework (MOF), the extension of a triangular linker leads to a different geometrical distribution of ligands and thus a porous structure with the topology of 3,3,9T2 for SNNU-80. Four types of polyhedral cages coexist together, which produce permanent micro- and mesoporosity. Different from MCF-18 assembled by BPYDB with [Ni3(OH)(COO)6] showing drastic framework breathing, SNNU-80 is not flexible. As a result, SNNU-80 shows remarkable CO2 uptake capacity as well as high CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons over CH4 selectivity. Furthermore, the electrochemical measurements show that SNNU-80 is an idea electrode material for supercapacitors due to its highly connected stable porous framework and the pseudocapacitor contribution introduced by the mixed valent system.

elements.content: The combination of trigonal prismatic building blocks and tripodal pyridyl-dicarboxylate linkers produces a mixed-valent highly connected hierarchical porous Co-metal−organic framework exhibiting remarkable gas uptake and separation properties as well as supercapacitor performance.
elements.clean_text: The combination of trigonal prismatic building blocks and tripodal pyridyl-dicarboxylate linkers produces a mixed-valent highly connected hierarchical porous Co-metal-organic framework exhibiting remarkable gas uptake and separation properties as well as supercapacitor performance.

elements.content: In the past 20 years, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed and extensively used for gas storage and separation, and so on. The high surface area, tunable pore surface, and scalability have made MOFs an attractive porous material. Up to now, a number of factors have been explored to develop novel high-performance MOFs materials. However, the directional design of high porous MOFs is still very challenging.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past 20 years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been rapidly developed and extensively used for gas storage and separation, and so on. The high surface area, tunable pore surface, and scalability have made MOFs an attractive porous material. Up to now, a number of factors have been explored to develop novel high-performance MOFs materials. However, the directional design of high porous MOFs is still very challenging.

elements.content: An effective route to design novel metal–organic frameworks is the utilization of extended geometrically equivalent organic linkers. For a given framework topology, the introduction of longer ligands usually can increase its pore size as well as its surface area. On the basis of this strategy, several famous MOF platforms have been successfully developed.
elements.clean_text: An effective route to design novel metal-organic frameworks is the utilization of extended geometrically equivalent organic linkers. For a given framework topology, the introduction of longer ligands usually can increase its pore size as well as its surface area. On the basis of this strategy, several famous MOF platforms have been successfully developed.

elements.content: We are especially interested in trinuclear cluster [M3(O/OH)­(COO)6]-based highly connected MOF platforms, such as 3,9-connected xmz MOFs and 9-conencted ncb MOFs, due to their high stability and potential flexibility. More recently, we have also developed another 3,9-connected MOF platform, namely, pacs MOFs (pacs = partitioned acs), which can accommodate a large variety of metal centers and allow for extraordinary tunability in gas sorption properties.
elements.clean_text: We are especially interested in trinuclear cluster [M3(O/OH)(COO)6]-based highly connected MOF platforms, such as 3,9-connected xmz MOFs and 9-conencted ncb MOFs, due to their high stability and potential flexibility. More recently, we have also developed another 3,9-connected MOF platform, namely, pacs MOFs (pacs = partitioned acs), which can accommodate a large variety of metal centers and allow for extraordinary tunability in gas sorption properties.

elements.content: Herein, 4,4′-(4,4′-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)-dibenzoic acid (H2BPYDB), an extended version of pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid, is selected to mimic the (3,9)-connected Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate xmz MOF (). However, the torsion of longer organic linker generates a new isomeric 3,3,9-connected framework, [Co3(OH)­(BPYDB)3] (SNNU-80). Compared to the nonporous Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate xmz MOF, SNNU-80 shows remarkable CO2 uptake capacity as well as high CO2 and C2-hydrocarbons over CH4 selectivity. Moreover, a Co3+/Co2+ mixed metal system exists in SNNU-80, which is rarely observed in both xmz and ncb MOF platforms. Taking the advantage of its highly connected stable porous framework and the pseudocapacitor contribution introduced by the mixed valent Co2+/Co3+ system, SNNU-80 shows good potential as an electrode material for supercapacitors.
elements.clean_text: Herein, 4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl)-dibenzoic acid (H2BPYDB), an extended version of pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylic acid, is selected to mimic the (3,9)-connected Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate xmz MOF (). However, the torsion of longer organic linker generates a new isomeric 3,3,9-connected framework, [Co3(OH)(BPYDB)3] (SNNU-80). Compared to the nonporous Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate xmz MOF, SNNU-80 shows remarkable CO2 uptake capacity as well as high CO2 and C2-hydrocarbons over CH4 selectivity. Moreover, a Co3+/Co2+ mixed metal system exists in SNNU-80, which is rarely observed in both xmz and ncb MOF platforms. Taking the advantage of its highly connected stable porous framework and the pseudocapacitor contribution introduced by the mixed valent Co2+/Co3+ system, SNNU-80 shows good potential as an electrode material for supercapacitors.

elements.content: All chemicals were obtained commercially. The ligand 4,4′-(4,4′-bipyridine-2,6-diyl) dibenzoic acid (H2BPYDB) was synthesized according to the literature method. Bruker EQUINOX-55 spectrophotometer was used to record the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra in the range 400–4000 cm–1. PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer was used to achieve the C, H, and N analysis. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a Q1000DSC+LNCS+FACS Q600SDT thermal analyzer. Raman spectra were done by an Invia Raman Microscope in the 400–3000 cm–1 range. D/Max2550VB+/PC diffractometer (CuK α, λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV and 40 mA) was used to finish the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were obtained commercially. The ligand 4,4'-(4,4'-bipyridine-2,6-diyl) dibenzoic acid (H2BPYDB) was synthesized according to the literature method. Bruker EQUINOX-55 spectrophotometer was used to record the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra in the range 400-4000 cm-1. PerkinElmer 2400 elemental analyzer was used to achieve the C, H, and N analysis. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a Q1000DSC+LNCS+FACS Q600SDT thermal analyzer. Raman spectra were done by an Invia Raman Microscope in the 400-3000 cm-1 range. D/Max2550VB+/PC diffractometer (CuK α, λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV and 40 mA) was used to finish the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements.

elements.content: [Co 3 (OH)­(BPYDB) 3 ] n ( SNNU-80 ). A mixture of H2BPYDB (0.008 g, 0.02 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.018 g, 0.06 mmol), N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL), and HBF4 (40%, 0.4 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air. The clear solution was transferred into a screw-capped vial (20 mL) and placed in an oven at 90 °C for 7 days. Purple block-shaped crystals were collected and washed with fresh DMA. Yield ∼65% (based on H2BPYDB). Anal. Calcd for C72H42N6O13Co3: C, 62.85; H, 42.34; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 62.16; H, 43.01; N, 6.19%. FT-IR (cm–1): 3422 (broad), 1595(s), 1387­(m), 1347(s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

 [Co 3 (OH)(BPYDB) 3 ]  n  (  SNNU-80  ). A mixture of H2BPYDB (0.008 g, 0.02 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.018 g, 0.06 mmol), N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL), and HBF4 (40%, 0.4 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air. The clear solution was transferred into a screw-capped vial (20 mL) and placed in an oven at 90 °C for 7 days. Purple block-shaped crystals were collected and washed with fresh DMA. Yield ~65% (based on H2BPYDB). Anal. Calcd for C72H42N6O13Co3: C, 62.85; H, 42.34; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 62.16; H, 43.01; N, 6.19%. FT-IR (cm-1): 3422 (broad), 1595(s), 1387(m), 1347(s).

elements.content: Single-crystal data of SNNU-80 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker FRAMBO CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized CuKα radiation (1.54178 Å). The structure of SNNU-80 was solved using the SHELXS-97 by the direct method. The SHELXL-97 program package was further used to refine the structure. The full matrix least-squares method was used to refine anisotropically for all non-hydrogen atoms. The SQUEEZE program in the PLATON software package was utilized to treat the disordered solvents entrapped in the pores.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Single-crystal data of SNNU-80 were collected at 293 K on a Bruker FRAMBO CCD diffractometer using graphite-monochromatized CuKα radiation (1.54178 Å). The structure of SNNU-80 was solved using the SHELXS-97 by the direct method. The SHELXL-97 program package was further used to refine the structure. The full matrix least-squares method was used to refine anisotropically for all non-hydrogen atoms. The SQUEEZE program in the PLATON software package was utilized to treat the disordered solvents entrapped in the pores.

elements.content: Gas sorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 surface-area and pore-size analyzer, and all used gases were of 99.99% purity. The gas sorption isotherms for CO2, CH4, C2H2, and C2H4 were measured at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms for N2 and H2 were measured at 77 K with liquid nitrogen. In order to ensure the actual equilibrium was reached, the equilibration interval time was set longer than 45 s for all experiments. Ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was further used to predict binary mixture adsorption from the experimental pure-gas isotherms. The single-component isotherms for CO2, C2H2, and C2H4 and CH4 of SNNU-80 are first fitted by the Langmuir–Freundlich (LF) equation. On the basis of the equation parameters, the separations of CO2/CH4, C2H2/CH4 and C2H4/CH4 were further calculated by the IAST model.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Adsorption and Selectivity Prediction

Gas sorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 surface-area and pore-size analyzer, and all used gases were of 99.99% purity. The gas sorption isotherms for CO2, CH4, C2H2, and C2H4 were measured at 273 and 298 K, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms for N2 and H2 were measured at 77 K with liquid nitrogen. In order to ensure the actual equilibrium was reached, the equilibration interval time was set longer than 45 s for all experiments. Ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) was further used to predict binary mixture adsorption from the experimental pure-gas isotherms. The single-component isotherms for CO2, C2H2, and C2H4 and CH4 of SNNU-80 are first fitted by the Langmuir-Freundlich (LF) equation. On the basis of the equation parameters, the separations of CO2/CH4, C2H2/CH4 and C2H4/CH4 were further calculated by the IAST model.

elements.content: 80% activated SNNU-80 (10 mg), 15% acetylene black together with 5% polyvinylidone fluoride (PVDF) binder were mixed to prepare the electrodes for supercapacitors. The mixture was made as a homogeneous slurry with a small amount of ethanol. The nickel foam (1 cm2) was selected as a current collector to load the slurry under 10 MPa pressure. Thus, the finial loading density of SNNU-80 was 10 mg cm–2. Before the electrochemical experiments, this self-made electrode was dried at 90 °C for 12 h.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

80% activated SNNU-80 (10 mg), 15% acetylene black together with 5% polyvinylidone fluoride (PVDF) binder were mixed to prepare the electrodes for supercapacitors. The mixture was made as a homogeneous slurry with a small amount of ethanol. The nickel foam (1 cm2) was selected as a current collector to load the slurry under 10 MPa pressure. Thus, the finial loading density of SNNU-80 was 10 mg cm-2. Before the electrochemical experiments, this self-made electrode was dried at 90 °C for 12 h.

elements.content: A typical three-electrode experimental setup was utilized to run all electrochemical measurements. SCE electrode, platinum foil, and self-made MOF electrode act as the reference, counter and working electrodes, respectively. 1 M KOH solution was used as the electrolyte. A CHI660E electrochemical working station system (Shanghai, China) was used to measure the cyclic voltammograms and galvanostatic charge–discharge in a given potential range and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy in the frequency range of 105 to 10–2 Hz at the room temperature.
elements.clean_text: A typical three-electrode experimental setup was utilized to run all electrochemical measurements. SCE electrode, platinum foil, and self-made MOF electrode act as the reference, counter and working electrodes, respectively. 1 M KOH solution was used as the electrolyte. A CHI660E electrochemical working station system (Shanghai, China) was used to measure the cyclic voltammograms and galvanostatic charge-discharge in a given potential range and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy in the frequency range of 105 to 10-2 Hz at the room temperature.

elements.content: It should be pointed out that using different cobalt salts to react with H2BPYDB resulted in different MOFs. Chen and co-workers reported a sulfate-supported (3,12)-connected framework on the basis of an octacobalt cluster through the reaction of CoSO4 and H2BPYDB under solvothermal conditions. When Co­(NO3)2 is utilized, Zhou and coworkers obtained PCN-121 on the basis of one-dimensional Co-chains with helical channels. Furthermore, with the addition of acetic acid to the reaction mixture, PCN-122 with Co-dimers was produced.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure

It should be pointed out that using different cobalt salts to react with H2BPYDB resulted in different MOFs. Chen and co-workers reported a sulfate-supported (3,12)-connected framework on the basis of an octacobalt cluster through the reaction of CoSO4 and H2BPYDB under solvothermal conditions. When Co(NO3)2 is utilized, Zhou and coworkers obtained PCN-121 on the basis of one-dimensional Co-chains with helical channels. Furthermore, with the addition of acetic acid to the reaction mixture, PCN-122 with Co-dimers was produced.

elements.content: In this work, when HBF4 is utilized instead of acetic acid under the same conditions, SNNU-80 formed. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that SNNU-80 crystallizes in the Pnma space group with the asymmetric unit containing crystallographically independent two Co, one μ3-OH, and one and half BPYDB ligands for the framework. The central oxygen links three Co cations to form a planar [Co3(OH)] cluster with the Co–O bonds and Co···Co separations of 2.022(5)–2.110(5) and 3.5083(15)–3.5127(13) Å, respectively. Each pair of Co centers are bridged by two carboxylate groups from separate BPYDB ligands above and below the [Co3(OH)] plane, which is encapsulated by six carboxylate groups and three pyridyl groups to form a [Co3(OH)­(CO2)6] building block. As shown in a, each [Co3(OH)­(CO2)6] trimer is connected to nine BPYDB ligands via six carboxylate groups and three Co–N bonds, and each BPYDB is connected to three Co-trimer clusters to give a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (b) of SNNU-80.
elements.clean_text: In this work, when HBF4 is utilized instead of acetic acid under the same conditions, SNNU-80 formed. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that SNNU-80 crystallizes in the Pnma space group with the asymmetric unit containing crystallographically independent two Co, one μ3-OH, and one and half BPYDB ligands for the framework. The central oxygen links three Co cations to form a planar [Co3(OH)] cluster with the Co-O bonds and Co⋅⋅⋅Co separations of 2.022(5)-2.110(5) and 3.5083(15)-3.5127(13) Å, respectively. Each pair of Co centers are bridged by two carboxylate groups from separate BPYDB ligands above and below the [Co3(OH)] plane, which is encapsulated by six carboxylate groups and three pyridyl groups to form a [Co3(OH)(CO2)6] building block. As shown in a, each [Co3(OH)(CO2)6] trimer is connected to nine BPYDB ligands via six carboxylate groups and three Co-N bonds, and each BPYDB is connected to three Co-trimer clusters to give a three-dimensional (3D) porous framework (b) of SNNU-80.

elements.content: (a) The distribution of nine BPYDB ligands around each [Co3(OH)­(CO2)6] cluster. (b) The 3D porous framework of SNNU-80 viewed along the a-axis direction.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The distribution of nine BPYDB ligands around each [Co3(OH)(CO2)6] cluster. (b) The 3D porous framework of SNNU-80 viewed along the a-axis direction.

elements.content: Overall, SNNU-80 exhibits a (3,3,9)-connected 3D framework with hydroxyl-centered [Co3(OH)­(CO2)6] tricapped trigonal prismatic clusters as 9-connected nodes and two unique BPYDB ligands as 3-connected nodes. The whole framework exhibits a 3,3,9T2 topological type with the short Schläfli symbol of {4.62}­{42.6}2­{48.619.89}. It should be pointed out that xmz Co-MOF has a (3,9)-connected net with the short Schläfli symbol of (42.6)3­(46.621.89). Clearly, the torsions induced by the large bulk of BPYDB ligands make SNNU-80 exhibit a different highly connected topological net compared to the Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate MOF (Figure S1). On the basis of BPYDB, Zhang and co-workers have synthesized an xmz-Ni MOF (MCF-18), which shows dramatic framework flexibility. It is interesting that on the base of nine-connected tricapped trigonal prismatic building blocks, another type of (3,9)-connected net (pacs MOFs) has also been explored by our group more recently. Each 9-connected trimeric building blocks in pacs MOFs connects to six adjacent trimers and three triangular ligands, which leads to a different short Schläfli symbol of (43)­(421.615) (Figure S2). Moreover, the local connectivity of these three (3,9)-connected MOFs are reminiscent of the inorganic compound LaCl3 because it also has similar 9- and 3-connected nodes (Figure S2) and shows a short Schläfli symbol of (43)3(412.615.89). Overall, such (3,9)-connectivity effectively fixes the framework and leads to well-defined and robust structures of MOFs, which are important for their further applications.
elements.clean_text: Overall, SNNU-80 exhibits a (3,3,9)-connected 3D framework with hydroxyl-centered [Co3(OH)(CO2)6] tricapped trigonal prismatic clusters as 9-connected nodes and two unique BPYDB ligands as 3-connected nodes. The whole framework exhibits a 3,3,9T2 topological type with the short Schläfli symbol of {4.62}{42.6}2{48.619.89}. It should be pointed out that xmz Co-MOF has a (3,9)-connected net with the short Schläfli symbol of (42.6)3(46.621.89). Clearly, the torsions induced by the large bulk of BPYDB ligands make SNNU-80 exhibit a different highly connected topological net compared to the Co-pyridine-3,5-dicarboxylate MOF (Figure S1). On the basis of BPYDB, Zhang and co-workers have synthesized an xmz-Ni MOF (MCF-18), which shows dramatic framework flexibility. It is interesting that on the base of nine-connected tricapped trigonal prismatic building blocks, another type of (3,9)-connected net (pacs MOFs) has also been explored by our group more recently. Each 9-connected trimeric building blocks in pacs MOFs connects to six adjacent trimers and three triangular ligands, which leads to a different short Schläfli symbol of (43)(421.615) (Figure S2). Moreover, the local connectivity of these three (3,9)-connected MOFs are reminiscent of the inorganic compound LaCl3 because it also has similar 9- and 3-connected nodes (Figure S2) and shows a short Schläfli symbol of (43)3(412.615.89). Overall, such (3,9)-connectivity effectively fixes the framework and leads to well-defined and robust structures of MOFs, which are important for their further applications.

elements.content: On the other hand, thanks to the longer BPYDB ligands, SNNU-80 clearly shows a porous structure. As defined by the tiling of 3,3,9T2 topology ([42.64]+3­[4.62]­+[43]+2­[63]), SNNU-80 possesses distorted octahedral, tetragonal–pyramidal, trigonal–bipyramidal, and tetrahedral cavities (denoted as cage-A, cage-B, cage-C, and cage-D) in a 1:3:1:2 ratio (). The dimensions of four types of cages are about 25 Å × 18 Å (cage A), 18 Å × 16 Å (cage B), 14 Å × 8 Å (cage C), and 17 Å × 16 Å (cage D), respectively. As shown in Figure S3, each cage-A connects with two cage-B, two cage-C, and two cage-D. Each cage-B connects with one cage-A, one cage-B, and one cage-D. Each cage-C connects with two cage-A and one cage-B. Each cage-D connects with one cage-A and two cage-B. Overall, four types of cages connected with each other via the face-sharing fashion to furnish a hierarchical channel-cavity biporous system of SNNU-80. Also, the guest accessible volume calculated by PLATON program is 11085.1 Å3, which occupies about 69.8% of the whole crystal volume.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, thanks to the longer BPYDB ligands, SNNU-80 clearly shows a porous structure. As defined by the tiling of 3,3,9T2 topology ([42.64]+3[4.62]+[43]+2[63]), SNNU-80 possesses distorted octahedral, tetragonal-pyramidal, trigonal-bipyramidal, and tetrahedral cavities (denoted as cage-A, cage-B, cage-C, and cage-D) in a 1:3:1:2 ratio (). The dimensions of four types of cages are about 25 Å × 18 Å (cage A), 18 Å × 16 Å (cage B), 14 Å × 8 Å (cage C), and 17 Å × 16 Å (cage D), respectively. As shown in Figure S3, each cage-A connects with two cage-B, two cage-C, and two cage-D. Each cage-B connects with one cage-A, one cage-B, and one cage-D. Each cage-C connects with two cage-A and one cage-B. Each cage-D connects with one cage-A and two cage-B. Overall, four types of cages connected with each other via the face-sharing fashion to furnish a hierarchical channel-cavity biporous system of SNNU-80. Also, the guest accessible volume calculated by PLATON program is 11085.1 Å3, which occupies about 69.8% of the whole crystal volume.

elements.content: Four types of polyhedral cages and the corresponding tilings for SNNU-80: (a) cage A, [42.64]; (b) cage B, [4.62]; (c) cage C, [43]; (d) cage D, [63]; (e) topological net and tilings.
elements.clean_text: 2  Four types of polyhedral cages and the corresponding tilings for SNNU-80: (a) cage A, [42.64]; (b) cage B, [4.62]; (c) cage C, [43]; (d) cage D, [63]; (e) topological net and tilings.

elements.content: The gas-adsorption studies were carried out with the activated sample to confirm the permanent porosity of SNNU-80. Freshly prepared SNNU-80 sample was confirmed by PXRD patterns (Figure S4) and can be easily activated through being soaked in volatile solvents such as ethanol, acetone, or CH2Cl2 to remove the DMA guest molecules. Different from MCF-18 assembled by the same ligand with [Ni3(OH)­(COO)6] showing drastic framework breathing upon inclusion of different guests, SNNU-80 is not flexible. This should be caused by their different 3,9-conencte topological nets. The thermogravimetric (TGA) results for fresh and activated samples all are shown in Figure S5. Solvent molecules of the unactivated sample are lost before 200 °C, and the thermal decomposition product at 800 °C is Co3O4 in air. But the activated Co-MOF loses solvent molecules below 100 °C and shows the stability of the framework between 100 and 375 °C. PXRD patterns for samples heated at different temperatures have also been given in Figure S5, which clearly prove the framework thermal stability. Such high thermal stability renders SNNU-80 a suitable candidate for gas sorption applications.
elements.clean_text:
Gas uptakes and Separations of CO2 or C2-Hydrocarbons from CH4 

The gas-adsorption studies were carried out with the activated sample to confirm the permanent porosity of SNNU-80. Freshly prepared SNNU-80 sample was confirmed by PXRD patterns (Figure S4) and can be easily activated through being soaked in volatile solvents such as ethanol, acetone, or CH2Cl2 to remove the DMA guest molecules. Different from MCF-18 assembled by the same ligand with [Ni3(OH)(COO)6] showing drastic framework breathing upon inclusion of different guests, SNNU-80 is not flexible. This should be caused by their different 3,9-conencte topological nets. The thermogravimetric (TGA) results for fresh and activated samples all are shown in Figure S5. Solvent molecules of the unactivated sample are lost before 200 °C, and the thermal decomposition product at 800 °C is Co3O4 in air. But the activated Co-MOF loses solvent molecules below 100 °C and shows the stability of the framework between 100 and 375 °C. PXRD patterns for samples heated at different temperatures have also been given in Figure S5, which clearly prove the framework thermal stability. Such high thermal stability renders SNNU-80 a suitable candidate for gas sorption applications.

elements.content: As depicted in a, the N2 adsorption isotherm indicates a Type-IV sorption behavior with a Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) surface area of 461 m2 g–1. It is typical for microporous materials with additional mesoporosity as a small degree of hysteresis was observed upon desorption. The permanent micro- and mesoporosity of SNNU-80 prompted us to further investigate their adsorptive properties of small gas molecules such as H2, CO2, CH4, C2H2, and C2H4.
elements.clean_text: As depicted in a, the N2 adsorption isotherm indicates a Type-IV sorption behavior with a Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) surface area of 461 m2 g-1. It is typical for microporous materials with additional mesoporosity as a small degree of hysteresis was observed upon desorption. The permanent micro- and mesoporosity of SNNU-80 prompted us to further investigate their adsorptive properties of small gas molecules such as H2, CO2, CH4, C2H2, and C2H4.

elements.content: Adsorption and desorption isotherms of N2 and H2 at 77 K (a), CO2, C2H2, C2H4, and CH4 at 273 and 298 K (b), and the gas selectivity predicted by IAST (c and d) for SNNU-80.
elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption and desorption isotherms of N2 and H2 at 77 K (a), CO2, C2H2, C2H4, and CH4 at 273 and 298 K (b), and the gas selectivity predicted by IAST (c and d) for SNNU-80.

elements.content: The low-pressure H2 sorption isotherms of SNNU-80 were given in a. At 77 K and 1 atm, the H2 uptake is 1.0 wt % (112 cm3 g–1), which is comparable to many famous frameworks such as MOF-5 (1.32 wt %) and MOF-177 (1.39 wt % at 1.4 atm) under the same conditions. The sorption behaviors of SNNU-80 toward CO2 (b) were investigated carefully. At 1 atm, the CO2 uptakes are 45.7 and 24.7 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. Furthermore, SNNU-80 can take up CH4 (8.3 cm3 g–1), C2H2 (70.2 cm3 g–1), and C2H4 (46.4 cm3 g–1) at 1 atm and 273 K. At 298 K and 1 atm, these values are CH4 (3.8 cm3 g–1), C2H2 (37.4 cm3 g–1), and C2H4 (28.8 cm3 g–1), respectively. To further understand the adsorption properties of SNNU-80, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was studied at 273 and 298 K by the virial model. At zero coverage, the Q st for C2H2, C2H4, CH4, and CO2 are 6.2, 12.6, 17.6, and 20.8 kJ/mol (Figures S6). Because of the absence of open metal sites in SNNU-80 framework, all the Q st values are remarkable lower than most of MOFs with open metal sites. Moreover, the CO2 and CH4 adsorption data are similar to PCN-121, another micro- and mesoporous MOF material with [Co3(OH)­(COO)6] building blocks and BPYDB ligands. Such adsorption capacities also inspired us to further investigate the separation of CO2, C2H2, and C2H4 from CH4 by SNUU-80.
elements.clean_text: The low-pressure H2 sorption isotherms of SNNU-80 were given in a. At 77 K and 1 atm, the H2 uptake is 1.0 wt % (112 cm3 g-1), which is comparable to many famous frameworks such as MOF-5 (1.32 wt %) and MOF-177 (1.39 wt % at 1.4 atm) under the same conditions. The sorption behaviors of SNNU-80 toward CO2 (b) were investigated carefully. At 1 atm, the CO2 uptakes are 45.7 and 24.7 cm3 g-1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. Furthermore, SNNU-80 can take up CH4 (8.3 cm3 g-1), C2H2 (70.2 cm3 g-1), and C2H4 (46.4 cm3 g-1) at 1 atm and 273 K. At 298 K and 1 atm, these values are CH4 (3.8 cm3 g-1), C2H2 (37.4 cm3 g-1), and C2H4 (28.8 cm3 g-1), respectively. To further understand the adsorption properties of SNNU-80, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was studied at 273 and 298 K by the virial model. At zero coverage, the Q st for C2H2, C2H4, CH4, and CO2 are 6.2, 12.6, 17.6, and 20.8 kJ/mol (Figures S6). Because of the absence of open metal sites in SNNU-80 framework, all the Q st values are remarkable lower than most of MOFs with open metal sites. Moreover, the CO2 and CH4 adsorption data are similar to PCN-121, another micro- and mesoporous MOF material with [Co3(OH)(COO)6] building blocks and BPYDB ligands. Such adsorption capacities also inspired us to further investigate the separation of CO2, C2H2, and C2H4 from CH4 by SNUU-80.

elements.content: An IAST calculation based on a Langmuir–Freundlich (LF) simulation was employed to establish the feasibility of these gas separations. At 273 K, for the mixtures composed of equimolar CO2 or C2-hydrocarbons to CH4 mixtures, the initial selectivity of SNNU-80 is 12.7, 17.5, and 11.3 for CO2/CH4, C2H2/CH4, and C2H4/CH4, respectively (c,d and S7). At 1 atm, these values increase to 170.0, 66.8, and 55.9. The CO2/CH4 selectivity is comparable to those of ZJU-60, MCF-18, JLU-Liu22, and 4-In-EBPTC. Furthermore, the C2H2/CH4 and C2H4/CH4 selectivities are also higher than many reported MOFs such as CoTZB­(INT) and ZJU-31 under similar conditions. In our opinion, the different polarizabilities of small gas molecules may help the CO2 or C2-hydrocarbon’s selectivity over CH4.
elements.clean_text: An IAST calculation based on a Langmuir-Freundlich (LF) simulation was employed to establish the feasibility of these gas separations. At 273 K, for the mixtures composed of equimolar CO2 or C2-hydrocarbons to CH4 mixtures, the initial selectivity of SNNU-80 is 12.7, 17.5, and 11.3 for CO2/CH4, C2H2/CH4, and C2H4/CH4, respectively (c,d and S7). At 1 atm, these values increase to 170.0, 66.8, and 55.9. The CO2/CH4 selectivity is comparable to those of ZJU-60, MCF-18, JLU-Liu22, and 4-In-EBPTC. Furthermore, the C2H2/CH4 and C2H4/CH4 selectivities are also higher than many reported MOFs such as CoTZB(INT) and ZJU-31 under similar conditions. In our opinion, the different polarizabilities of small gas molecules may help the CO2 or C2-hydrocarbon's selectivity over CH4.

elements.content: The highly connected stable framework, hierarchical pore structure together with the mixed valent Co2+/Co3+ system of SNNU-80 provoked us to further investigate its potential applications in supercapacitors. To the best of our knowledge, although metal oxides synthesized from MOF precursors have been extensively reported as electrode materials of supercapacitor, rare MOFs have been directly utilized up to now.
elements.clean_text:
Supercapacitor Performance

The highly connected stable framework, hierarchical pore structure together with the mixed valent Co2+/Co3+ system of SNNU-80 provoked us to further investigate its potential applications in supercapacitors. To the best of our knowledge, although metal oxides synthesized from MOF precursors have been extensively reported as electrode materials of supercapacitor, rare MOFs have been directly utilized up to now.

elements.content: a shows that the cyclic voltammetric (CV) behaviors of SNNU-80 have obvious redox peaks at various scan rates from 5 to 100 mV s–1 within the range 0.1–0.4 V for the character of faradaic pseudocapacitance due to Co3+ and Co2+ ions’ redox reaction in alkaline electrolyte. Under different scan rates, the CV curves of the SNNU-80 MOF electrode reveal that the electrochemical capacitance for SNNU-80 should result from pseudocapacitance. The average specific capacitances have been calculated 109.3, 97.8, 89.4, 76.2, and 67.8 F g–1 at scan rates of 5, 10, 20, 50, and 100 mV s–1, respectively. Clearly, with an increase of the scan rate, the capacitance decreases continuously. This may caused by the circuitous diffusion of electrolyte ions into the pores of SNNU-80 MOF and the electrode resistance. That is to say, the Co-MOF electrode exhibits pseudocapacitance induced by electrochemical reactions. This result is quite different from the double-layer capacitor, which basically has an ideal rectangular shaped CV curve. Moreover, the peak current increases continuously with the scan rate ranging from 5 to 100 mV s–1.
elements.clean_text: a shows that the cyclic voltammetric (CV) behaviors of SNNU-80 have obvious redox peaks at various scan rates from 5 to 100 mV s-1 within the range 0.1-0.4 V for the character of faradaic pseudocapacitance due to Co3+ and Co2+ ions' redox reaction in alkaline electrolyte. Under different scan rates, the CV curves of the SNNU-80 MOF electrode reveal that the electrochemical capacitance for SNNU-80 should result from pseudocapacitance. The average specific capacitances have been calculated 109.3, 97.8, 89.4, 76.2, and 67.8 F g-1 at scan rates of 5, 10, 20, 50, and 100 mV s-1, respectively. Clearly, with an increase of the scan rate, the capacitance decreases continuously. This may caused by the circuitous diffusion of electrolyte ions into the pores of SNNU-80 MOF and the electrode resistance. That is to say, the Co-MOF electrode exhibits pseudocapacitance induced by electrochemical reactions. This result is quite different from the double-layer capacitor, which basically has an ideal rectangular shaped CV curve. Moreover, the peak current increases continuously with the scan rate ranging from 5 to 100 mV s-1.

elements.content: Supercapacitor performance of SNNU-80 MOF electrode: (a) cyclic voltammograms in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte at different scan rates; (b) galvanostatic charge–discharge curves at different current densities; (c) average specific capacitance versus cycle number at a galvanostatic charge–discharge current density of 5 A g–1; (d) cyclic voltammograms at the scan rate of 10 mV s–1 before and after galvanostatic charging–discharging for 3000 cycles at the current density of 5 A g–1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Supercapacitor performance of SNNU-80 MOF electrode: (a) cyclic voltammograms in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte at different scan rates; (b) galvanostatic charge-discharge curves at different current densities; (c) average specific capacitance versus cycle number at a galvanostatic charge-discharge current density of 5 A g-1; (d) cyclic voltammograms at the scan rate of 10 mV s-1 before and after galvanostatic charging-discharging for 3000 cycles at the current density of 5 A g-1.

elements.content: The constant current charge–discharge tests in the potential range between 0 and 0.4 V were investigated to obtain the specific capacitances of the SNNU-80 electrode (b). The specific capacitance (C m) can be calculated using the following equation: C m = I Δ t / m Δ V where I is the current of charge–discharge, Δt is the time of discharge, m is the mass of active materials in the work electrode, and ΔV is 0.4 V.
elements.clean_text: The constant current charge-discharge tests in the potential range between 0 and 0.4 V were investigated to obtain the specific capacitances of the SNNU-80 electrode (b). The specific capacitance (C m) can be calculated using the following equation: 1      C   m   = I Δ t / m Δ V   where I is the current of charge-discharge, Δt is the time of discharge, m is the mass of active materials in the work electrode, and ΔV is 0.4 V.

elements.content: An obvious voltage drop can be observed from the curves and that display approximate triangular shapes at various currents. As a result, the specific capacitance values of SNNU-80 electrode are measured to be 106, 94, and 88 F g–1 at charge–discharge current densities of 1, 2, and 3 A g–1, respectively. These values are much higher than those of Co8-MOF-5 and comparable to the results of other Co-MOFs (Co-BDC, Co-NDC, and Co-BPDC) and mesoporous 437-MOF.
elements.clean_text: An obvious voltage drop can be observed from the curves and that display approximate triangular shapes at various currents. As a result, the specific capacitance values of SNNU-80 electrode are measured to be 106, 94, and 88 F g-1 at charge-discharge current densities of 1, 2, and 3 A g-1, respectively. These values are much higher than those of Co8-MOF-5 and comparable to the results of other Co-MOFs (Co-BDC, Co-NDC, and Co-BPDC) and mesoporous 437-MOF.

elements.content: Furthermore, the long-term cycling performance of SNNU-80 electrode was measured at constant current density of 5 A g–1 as shown in c. There was only a 5.29% capacitance loss observed over 3000 cycles. Also, the PXRD patterns (Figure S4), FT-IR, and Raman spectra (Figure S8) of the working electrode before and after electrochemical performance test clearly showed the stability of SNNU-80 MOF electrode. Clearly, the 9-connected net effectively helps to stabilize the framework during the electrochemical process.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the long-term cycling performance of SNNU-80 electrode was measured at constant current density of 5 A g-1 as shown in c. There was only a 5.29% capacitance loss observed over 3000 cycles. Also, the PXRD patterns (Figure S4), FT-IR, and Raman spectra (Figure S8) of the working electrode before and after electrochemical performance test clearly showed the stability of SNNU-80 MOF electrode. Clearly, the 9-connected net effectively helps to stabilize the framework during the electrochemical process.

elements.content: Moreover, the Nyquist plots of Co-MOF electrode indicate that the equivalent series resistance was 3.1 Ω (Figure S9). This suggests that Co-MOF material can enable high electron mobility through the electrode to facilitate the electron transfer. Moreover, in the low-frequency region, the linear response represents an interfacial diffusive resistance. SNNU-80 electrode exhibiting slight deviation from the imaginary axis indicates that the electrode has a low diffusive resistance. From these observations, this Co-MOF electrode’s high specific capacitance can be attributed to its low serial and diffusive resistance. The change of CV curves for SNNU-80 MOF electrode before and after 3000 cycles is shown in d. After 3000 cycles, the redox peaks are more obvious due to sufficient faradic redox reaction at higher current densities of the electrode materials, which suggests its good reversibility.
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the Nyquist plots of Co-MOF electrode indicate that the equivalent series resistance was 3.1 Ω (Figure S9). This suggests that Co-MOF material can enable high electron mobility through the electrode to facilitate the electron transfer. Moreover, in the low-frequency region, the linear response represents an interfacial diffusive resistance. SNNU-80 electrode exhibiting slight deviation from the imaginary axis indicates that the electrode has a low diffusive resistance. From these observations, this Co-MOF electrode's high specific capacitance can be attributed to its low serial and diffusive resistance. The change of CV curves for SNNU-80 MOF electrode before and after 3000 cycles is shown in d. After 3000 cycles, the redox peaks are more obvious due to sufficient faradic redox reaction at higher current densities of the electrode materials, which suggests its good reversibility.

elements.content: In summary, a unique highly connected micro- and mesoporous Co-MOF material on the basis of Co3-trigonal prismatic building blocks and tripodal pyridyl-dicarboxylate ligands has been successfully designed by the ligand extension method. The torsions induced by the large bulk of the organic linker make the Co-MOF exhibit a different topological net compared to the initial xmz MOF. Four types of polyhedral cages connect to each other via a face-sharing fashion to furnish a hierarchical channel-cavity biporous system of the Co-MOF. Thanks to a highly connected robust porous framework and the pseudocapacitor contribution, the Co-MOF shows remarkable gas adsorption and separation properties as well as supercapacitor performance.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a unique highly connected micro- and mesoporous Co-MOF material on the basis of Co3-trigonal prismatic building blocks and tripodal pyridyl-dicarboxylate ligands has been successfully designed by the ligand extension method. The torsions induced by the large bulk of the organic linker make the Co-MOF exhibit a different topological net compared to the initial xmz MOF. Four types of polyhedral cages connect to each other via a face-sharing fashion to furnish a hierarchical channel-cavity biporous system of the Co-MOF. Thanks to a highly connected robust porous framework and the pseudocapacitor contribution, the Co-MOF shows remarkable gas adsorption and separation properties as well as supercapacitor performance.

cln_elements.content: [Co 3 (OH)­(BPYDB) 3 ] n ( SNNU-80 ). A mixture of H2BPYDB (0.008 g, 0.02 mmol), Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.018 g, 0.06 mmol), N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL), and HBF4 (40%, 0.4 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air. The clear solution was transferred into a screw-capped vial (20 mL) and placed in an oven at 90 °C for 7 days. Purple block-shaped crystals were collected and washed with fresh DMA. Yield ∼65% (based on H2BPYDB). Anal. Calcd for C72H42N6O13Co3: C, 62.85; H, 42.34; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 62.16; H, 43.01; N, 6.19%. FT-IR (cm–1): 3422 (broad), 1595(s), 1387­(m), 1347(s).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

 [Co 3 (OH)(BPYDB) 3 ]  n  (  SNNU-80  ). A mixture of H2BPYDB (0.008 g, 0.02 mmol), Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.018 g, 0.06 mmol), N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 3 mL), and HBF4 (40%, 0.4 mL) was stirred for 30 min in air. The clear solution was transferred into a screw-capped vial (20 mL) and placed in an oven at 90 °C for 7 days. Purple block-shaped crystals were collected and washed with fresh DMA. Yield ~65% (based on H2BPYDB). Anal. Calcd for C72H42N6O13Co3: C, 62.85; H, 42.34; N, 6.21%. Found: C, 62.16; H, 43.01; N, 6.19%. FT-IR (cm-1): 3422 (broad), 1595(s), 1387(m), 1347(s).

cln_elements.content:
As depicted in a, the N2 adsorption isotherm indicates a Type-IV sorption behavior with a Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) surface area of 461 m2 g–1. It is typical for microporous materials with additional mesoporosity as a small degree of hysteresis was observed upon desorption. The permanent micro- and mesoporosity of SNNU-80 prompted us to further investigate their adsorptive properties of small gas molecules such as H2, CO2, CH4, C2H2, and C2H4.

The low-pressure H2 sorption isotherms of SNNU-80 were given in a. At 77 K and 1 atm, the H2 uptake is 1.0 wt % (112 cm3 g–1), which is comparable to many famous frameworks such as MOF-5 (1.32 wt %) and MOF-177 (1.39 wt % at 1.4 atm) under the same conditions. The sorption behaviors of SNNU-80 toward CO2 (b) were investigated carefully. At 1 atm, the CO2 uptakes are 45.7 and 24.7 cm3 g–1 at 273 and 298 K, respectively. Furthermore, SNNU-80 can take up CH4 (8.3 cm3 g–1), C2H2 (70.2 cm3 g–1), and C2H4 (46.4 cm3 g–1) at 1 atm and 273 K. At 298 K and 1 atm, these values are CH4 (3.8 cm3 g–1), C2H2 (37.4 cm3 g–1), and C2H4 (28.8 cm3 g–1), respectively. To further understand the adsorption properties of SNNU-80, the isosteric heat of adsorption (Q st) was studied at 273 and 298 K by the virial model. At zero coverage, the Q st for C2H2, C2H4, CH4, and CO2 are 6.2, 12.6, 17.6, and 20.8 kJ/mol (Figures S6). Because of the absence of open metal sites in SNNU-80 framework, all the Q st values are remarkable lower than most of MOFs with open metal sites. Moreover, the CO2 and CH4 adsorption data are similar to PCN-121, another micro- and mesoporous MOF material with [Co3(OH)­(COO)6] building blocks and BPYDB ligands. Such adsorption capacities also inspired us to further investigate the separation of CO2, C2H2, and C2H4 from CH4 by SNUU-80.

At 77 K and 1 atm, the H2 uptake is 1.0 wt % (112 cm3 g-1), which is comparable to many famous frameworks such as MOF-5 (1.32 wt %) and MOF-177 (1.39 wt % at 1.4 atm) under the same conditions. At zero coverage, the Q st for C2H2, C2H4, CH4, and CO2 are 6.2, 12.6, 17.6, and 20.8 kJ/mol (Figures S6). cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption and desorption isotherms of N2 and H2 at 77 K (a), CO2, C2H2, C2H4, and CH4 at 273 and 298 K (b), and the gas selectivity predicted by IAST (c and d) for SNNU-80.

cln_elements.content: Supercapacitor performance of SNNU-80 MOF electrode: (a) cyclic voltammograms in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte at different scan rates; (b) galvanostatic charge–discharge curves at different current densities; (c) average specific capacitance versus cycle number at a galvanostatic charge–discharge current density of 5 A g–1; (d) cyclic voltammograms at the scan rate of 10 mV s–1 before and after galvanostatic charging–discharging for 3000 cycles at the current density of 5 A g–1.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Supercapacitor performance of SNNU-80 MOF electrode: (a) cyclic voltammograms in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte at different scan rates; (b) galvanostatic charge-discharge curves at different current densities; (c) average specific capacitance versus cycle number at a galvanostatic charge-discharge current density of 5 A g-1; (d) cyclic voltammograms at the scan rate of 10 mV s-1 before and after galvanostatic charging-discharging for 3000 cycles at the current density of 5 A g-1.

metadata.title:
Gas Uptake and Supercapacitor Performance of a Highly
Connected Porous Co-Metal–Organic Framework Induced by Ligand
Bulk
